content.user_profile:
The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have -- this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests.
Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.
User profile:
```Preferred name: E-Jay
Role: Mathematics Researcher
Other Information: About Myself: 
I have mathematical knowledge up to graduate level.

Current interests:
(1) coding: mainly Python
(2) machine learning and artificial intelligence
```
content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

Be precise and comprehensive in your analysis. Don't sugar-coat responses. Be as objective as possible. Critique and question my views if necessary. Take a forward-thinking view.

Define highly technical or specialized abbreviations in full before using them.```

entries.title: OpenAI's Codex developer agent just got a big update
entries.snippet:
OpenAI has announced a major update to its Codex developer agent, significantly expanding its availability and functionality. Codex can now be accessed directly within terminals, IDEs like Visual Studio Code and Cursor, GitHub, and the ChatGPT iOS app, enabling developers to utilize it seamlessly across environments without switching tools. A new IDE extension allows developers to sign in with their ChatGPT accounts for integrated access, removing the need for API key setups. Key features include hands-free code reviews on GitHub—users can tag @codex in pull requests—and the ability to delegate compute tasks to the cloud without losing project state.

The update introduces a refreshed UI, added commands, and bug fixes. While these features are available immediately, support for some enterprise and educational accounts is still rolling out. This development comes shortly after OpenAI's failed acquisition of the AI coding company Windsurf, which was purchased by Cognition. The update follows broader industry trends, with AWS, Google, Microsoft, and GitHub all enhancing their AI coding tools. Codex remains accessible only to paid ChatGPT subscribers across Plus, Pro, Team, Edu, and Enterprise plans.

parts:
Here are the current, official install steps to get **OpenAI Codex CLI** working **inside WSL (Ubuntu/Debian/etc.)**.

## 1) Ensure Node.js + npm are available in WSL
Codex CLI is distributed via **npm** (Node Package Manager). The official docs install it with npm. citeturn0search1turn0search4

In WSL, you can use any normal Linux Node setup. A common, reliable approach is **nvm** (Node Version Manager), but if you already have Node/npm, you can skip to step 2.

Quick checks:
```bash
node -v
npm -v
```

If you need Node, install it (example using nvm):
```bash
# install nvm (follow nvm's official instructions if you prefer)
curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nvm-sh/nvm/v0.39.7/install.sh | bash
# restart your shell, then:
nvm install --lts
nvm use --lts
node -v
npm -v
```

## 2) Install Codex CLI in WSL
Official install command (global):
```bash
npm i -g @openai/codex
```
This is exactly what OpenAI’s Codex CLI docs and quickstart specify. citeturn0search1turn0search4turn0search2

## 3) Run Codex and authenticate
Start it:
```bash
codex
```

On first run, Codex will prompt you to sign in—either with your **ChatGPT account** or an **OpenAI API key**, per the official docs. citeturn0search1turn0search4

## 4) If `codex` isn’t found (common WSL PATH issue)
This usually means npm’s global bin directory isn’t on your PATH.

Check where npm installs global bins:
```bash
npm bin -g
```

Then add that directory to your PATH in `~/.bashrc` or `~/.zshrc`, e.g.:
```bash
export PATH="$PATH:$(npm bin -g)"
```

Reload your shell:
```bash
source ~/.bashrc   # or ~/.zshrc
```

## 5) Alternative install path (if you don’t want npm)
OpenAI’s Codex repo notes you can also download a **platform-appropriate binary** from GitHub Releases. citeturn0search2  
(That’s more manual, but can be useful if you’re avoiding Node/npm in WSL.)

If you tell me your WSL distro (Ubuntu 22.04? 24.04?) and how you prefer to manage Node (apt vs nvm vs asdf), I can give you the cleanest exact command sequence for that setup.
